newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian shares end down on politics, result worries.
newsitem.headline: Indian shares end down on politics, result worries.

text.p: ** Indian shares finish lower on Thursday as disappointing corporate results continue to pour in, traders say
** The adjournment of parliament for a second consecutive day makes investors in Delhi jittery
** Bombay's benchmark index falls 19.2 points to 3043.30, National Stock Exchange index ends 6.79 points down at 869.82
** Shares of Tata Chemicals hit after first half net falls below last year; Tata Tea ends lower as results fail to cheer
** April-September industrial growth slows to 4.8 percent from 12.8 percent during the corresponding period last year
** Finance firm IDBI reports modest 2.0 percent growth in net for the six months to September 30, 1996
Indian shares closed lower on Thursday as disappointing first half results continued to pour in and traders said unpleasant surprises were still in store.
"There was quite a bit of selling in pivotals probably due to the bad results and the news that industrial production figures are down," said a trader at a foreign brokerage.
India's April-September industrial growth has slowed to 4.8 percent from 12.8 percent during the corresponding period last year, according to the latest data released on Wednesday.
"Investors are waiting for some positive signal," the trader said.

A study by securities firm Dil Vikas Finance Ltd found first half results of Indian companies announced so far have shown a modest 4.0 percent growth in net profit and a 2.1 percent fall in earnings. The study included a sample of 181 firms which announced results until November 19.
R. Balakrishnan, president at Dil Vikas said second half performance would largely depend on commodity prices in the remaining part of 1996/97 (April-March).
"Interest rates have not declined across-the-board as the prime lending rate (PLR) reduction benefits just a handful of companies," he said.
Shares of Tata Chemicals -- which announced a fall in first half net on Wednesday -- fell 9.75 percent to 180.50 rupees.
Finance firm IDBI's results fell below market expectations.

Tata Tea shares were not cheered by a 25 percent jump in first half net. The firm said the year-ago figure was adjusted for impact of increased wages. It said profit margins in the second half would be hit on the back of falling tea prices.

In Delhi, shares ended sharply lower on nervous selling by foreign funds after parliament adjourned for a second successive day. The index ended 9.37 points down at 676.16. -- Priya Ramani, Bombay newsroom +91-22-265 9000
